Federated Learning via Unmanned Aerial Vehicle

Min Fu, , Yuanming Shi, , and Yong Zhou M. Fu is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117583 (e-mail: fumin@u.nus.edu). Y. Shi and Y. Zhou are with School of Information Science and Technology, ShanghaiTech University, Shanghai 201210, China (e-mail: {shiym, zhouyong}@shanghaitech.edu.cn).
Abstract

To enable communication-efficient federated learning (FL), this paper studies an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-enabled FL system, where the UAV coordinates distributed ground devices for a shared model training. Specifically, by exploiting the UAV’s high altitude and mobility, the UAV can proactively establish short-distance line-of-sight links with devices and prevent any device from being a communication straggler. Thus, the model aggregation process can be accelerated while the cumulative model loss caused by device scheduling can be reduced, resulting in a decreased completion time. We first present the convergence analysis of FL without the assumption of convexity, demonstrating the effect of device scheduling on the global gradients. Based on the derived convergence bound, we further formulate the completion time minimization problem by jointly optimizing device scheduling, UAV trajectory, and time allocation. This problem explicitly incorporates the devices’ energy budgets, dynamic channel conditions, and convergence accuracy of FL constraints. Despite the non-convexity of the formulated problem, we exploit its structure to decompose it into two sub-problems and further derive the optimal solutions via the Lagrange dual ascent method. Simulation results show that the proposed design significantly improves the tradeoff between completion time and prediction accuracy in practical FL settings compared to existing benchmarks.

Index Terms:
Federated leaning, UAV communications, completion time minimization, device scheduling, and UAV trajectory design.

I Introduction

As the storage and computation capabilities of edge devices keep growing, it becomes more attractive to process the data locally and push network computation to the edge [1, 2, 3]. In the field of machine learning (ML), distributed learning frameworks [4, 5] that keep the training data locally are well developed to protect data privacy and reduce network energy/time costs. Recently, federated learning (FL) [4, 5, 1] has been proposed as a promising solution for distributed ML, which enables multiple devices to execute local training on their own dataset and collaboratively build a shared ML model with the coordination of a parameter server (PS) (e.g., access point and base station). Since only model parameters rather than raw data are exchanged between devices and the PS, FL significantly relieves the communication burden and protects data privacy[4, 6] with wide-field applications, e.g., vehicle-to-vehicle communications [7] and content recommendations for smartphones[5].

In contrast to the centralized ML, the PS in FL needs to exchange models with multiple devices over hundreds to thousands of communication rounds to achieve the desired training accuracy. However, the main challenge in realizing FL on wireless networks arises from communication stragglers with unfavorable links [8, 9]. For example, in over-the-air computation (AirComp)-based analog FL [6, 10], communication stragglers dominate the overall model aggregation error caused by channel fading and communication noise since the devices with better channel qualities have to reduce their transmit power for the local models’ alignment at the PS. Moreover, in digital synchronous FL [11, 8], communication stragglers significantly slow down the model aggregation process and dominate cumulative communication delay since the PS must wait until receiving the training updates from all participants. If the number of communication stragglers is high, the overall communication delay will be unacceptable. The straggler issue is thus the main bottleneck to design communication-efficient FL systems.

There have been many efforts to mitigate the communication straggler effect in FL, such as device scheduling [6, 10, 11]. For instance, to reduce model misalignment error incurred by stragglers in AirComp-based FL, the authors in [6, 10] scheduled the devices with reliable channels for concurrent model uploading. In addition, to reduce the communication delay incurred by stragglers in digital FL, devices with large contributions to the global model [11] or/and with favorable channel conditions [12, 13] are generally selected. Nevertheless, because such device scheduling is biased, which results in a smaller amount of training data utilized, this, in turn, may damage the update of the global model and decrease the learning performance of FL. To alleviate such communication-learning tradeoff, recent research has investigated the integration of advanced technologies (i.e., relays [14], reconfigurable intelligent surfaces [15, 16, 17]) into FL systems to improve stragglers’ communication qualities and thus further upgrade device scheduling policy for the reduction of communication errors. These existing frameworks require a terrestrial BS to provide network coverage to the devices for model aggregation. However, many FL tasks need to be performed under the circumstances when terrestrial networks are unavailable in remote areas. For example, devices from multiple regions (e.g., forests and woodlands) can collaborate through FL to build a learning model for fire monitoring [18]. Under these harsh environments, it is imperative to deploy a more flexible PS that proactively establishes favorable communication links among devices.

As a viable complementary alternative to terrestrial networks, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) can provide coverage extension and seamless connectivity to support various FL tasks, especially in distant and underdeveloped areas [19, 20, 21]. Inspired by this, this paper studies a UAV-enabled FL network, where a UAV is dispatched as a flying PS to aggregate and update the digital FL model parameters when no terrestrial BS is available. To mitigate the communication straggler effect in UAV-enabled FL networks, we propose to jointly design UAV trajectory and device scheduling. First, the qualities of communication channels between the UAV and devices still differ since all links’ channel conditions depend on the UAV’s location at each time slot. To address this issue, device scheduling is necessary to prevent communication stragglers. Furthermore, by utilizing its mobility, the UAV can establish short-distance LoS links to scheduled devices. As a result, each scheduled device achieves a high data rate for model uploading, resulting in faster model uploads/downloads per round compared to the static UAV. In addition, with its ability to dynamically adjust communication distances, the UAV can prevent any device from being a communication straggler all the time, ensuring that all devices have the opportunity to participate in FL training. As such, incorporated with UAV trajectory planning, the optimized device scheduling strategy focuses on data exploitation maximization, thereby reducing cumulative model aggregation loss and accelerating FL convergence. Hence, such join design in UAV-enabled FL networks is an appealing solution to address the straggler issue and reduce communication time.

Motivated by the above observations, in this paper, we focus on the time required for completing the FL training process [22, 23], which includes not only the computation time but also the communication time of all scheduled devices. The completion time is a critical design aspect in UAV-enabled systems, as UAVs usually have a limited endurance due to the practical physical constraints [24]. Additionally, devices generally have a limited energy budget without battery replacement or recharging [9]. Thus, the formulated optimization problem needs to consider not only the FL constraints such as the target convergence accuracy level but also the devices’ dynamic communication conditions such as energy consumption. As such, this paper aims to minimize the completion time of UAV-enabled FL by jointly optimizing the UAV trajectory, device scheduling, and time allocation for energy-constrained devices, while ensuring that the FL algorithm can converge to a target accuracy.

I-A Contributions

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We consider a novel UAV-enabled FL framework, where a mobile UAV is dispatched as a PS to exchange the model parameters with devices, thereby preventing devices from being communication stragglers. Moreover, under the convergence accuracy of FL constraint, we mainly focus on the completion time minimization problem for UAV-enabled FL systems. This consideration is of paramount importance for latency-critical FL applications and limited endurance UAV systems.

  • •

    We first derive an upper bound on the iterative norm of the global gradients for non-convex loss functions, taking model update errors from device selection into account. Specifically, the analytical bound shows that the device selection loss causes convergence rate reduction and leads to a non-diminishing gap between the initial model and the global optimum of the training loss.

  • •

    Based on the convergence bound, we formulate the completion time minimization problem by jointly designing device scheduling, communication time allocation for scheduled devices, and trajectory planning for UAV, taking into account the target convergence accuracy of FL, energy budget at devices, and practical constraints at the UAV. Besides, we quantitatively analyze the fundamental tradeoff between learning accuracy and communication latency, and demonstrate the importance of the mobile UAV in the proposed system.

  • •

    Although the formulated mixed-integer nonconvex problem is high intractable, we propose an efficient iterative block coordinate descent (BCD) algorithm to solve the joint device scheduling and time allocation optimization subproblem and the UAV trajectory optimization subproblem alternately, which is guaranteed to converge. Moreover, to reduce computational complexity, each optimization subproblem is solved optimally with a closed-form solution by applying the Lagrange duality method.

Simulation results in realistic federated settings are provided to illustrate the learning-communication tradeoff and validate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme. Specifically, the proposed joint design scheme outperforms existing benchmark schemes in terms of mission completion time, which is appealing in light of the limited endurance of UAVs. Moreover, our proposed scheme provides comparable performance to the full-scheduling ideal benchmark in terms of prediction accuracy, even when the target convergence accuracy of FL is relatively large.

I-B Related Work

I-B1 UAV Assisted FL Networks

Upon the completion of this work, the application of UAV in FL networks was investigated in some parallel works [25, 26, 27, 28] Specifically, the authors in [25] developed a novel FL framework with UAV swarms to improve the FL learning efficiency. The authors in [26] proposed an FL-based sensing and collaborative learning approach for UAV-enabled internet of vehicles (IoVs), where UAVs as devices collect data and train ML models for IoVs. In addition, [27] described using UAVs as flight relays to support wireless communication between IoVs and the FL server, thus enhancing FL accuracy. The authors in [28] studied the deployment of multiple UAVs as flying BSs to minimize the weighted sum of FL execution time and function loss. Nevertheless, this work does not consider device budget issues that may affect FL performance and convergence cannot be guaranteed.

I-B2 Latency Minimization Problems in FL Networks

A few works have studied the completion time minimization problems in different FL scenarios. The authors in [22] formulated an FL framework over a wireless network as an optimization problem that minimizes the sum of FL aggregation latency and total device energy consumption. In addition, the authors in [29] investigated the tradeoff between the FL convergence time and devices’ energy consumption. However, in [22, 29], all devices are assumed to be involved in each round.

I-C Organization

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the FL via the UAV system model. In Section III, we provide the convergence analysis of FL and completion time minimization problem formulation. In Section IV, we propose a BCD method to solve the formulated problem. Section V presents the numerical results to evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithm. Finally, we conclude this paper in Section VI.

II System Model

We consider a UAV-assisted FL network that consists of a single-antenna UAV and a set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} of K𝐾K single-antenna devices, aiming to collaboratively learn an ML model (e.g., logistic regression and linear regression). Since the terrestrial BSs are usually sparsely deployed or unavailable in rural, remote, and underdeveloped areas, we deploy an UAV with a powerful processor to act as a PS in these harsh circumstances.

Each device k𝑘k has a local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} with size Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. Local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} is a collection of data samples {𝒙k​i,yk​i}i=1Dksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘\{\bm{x}_{ki},y_{ki}\}_{i=1}^{D_{k}}, where 𝒙k​i∈ℝdsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{x}_{ki}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the input sample vector with d𝑑d features and yk​i∈ℝsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑖ℝy_{ki}\in\mathbb{R} is the label for sample 𝒙k​isubscript𝒙𝑘𝑖\bm{x}_{ki}. The UAV-enabled FL system aims to cooperatively learn an ML model under the coordination of the UAV in an iterative manner while keeping the local training data on mobile devices. In the sequel, we describe FL over UAV-enabled wireless networks, as summarized in Algorithm 1.

II-A FL Training Model

Let 𝒘∈ℝd𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and 𝒘k∈ℝdsubscript𝒘𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be the global model parameters at the UAV and the local model parameters at the k𝑘k-th device, respectively. The local loss function of device k𝑘k is defined as

subject to 𝒘1=⋯=𝒘K=𝒘,subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘𝐾𝒘\displaystyle\bm{w}_{1}=\cdots=\bm{w}_{K}=\bm{w}, (3)

where constraint (3) is used to ensure that all devices and the server have the same model after the FL algorithm converges. To solve problem (II-A), the training procedure of FL consists of multiple communication rounds. Therein, in a communication round, the devices update the local models based on their own data and a common model initialization from the PS. After that, they contribute to the global model at the PS by uploading model updates over the wireless channel, as described below.

First, the UAV determines the set of devices that participate in the current round. Let ak​[n]∈{0,1}subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛01a_{k}[n]\in\{0,1\} denote the scheduling variable for device k𝑘k in the n𝑛n-th round. Therein, ak​[n]=1subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1a_{k}[n]=1 indicates that device k𝑘k sends its updated local model to the UAV at communication round n𝑛n; otherwise we have ak​[n]=0subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛0a_{k}[n]=0. 𝒜nsubscript𝒜𝑛\mathcal{A}_{n} is defined as the set of scheduled devices in the n𝑛n-th round. Then, the UAV broadcasts the current global model, denoted by 𝒘n−1subscript𝒘𝑛1\bm{w}_{n-1}, to all the scheduled devices.

Each scheduled device k∈𝒜n𝑘subscript𝒜𝑛k\in\mathcal{A}_{n} receives the global model and updates its local model by applying the gradient descent algorithm [11, 8] on its local dataset:

𝒘k,n=𝒘n−1−ηDk​∑(xk​i,yk​i)∈𝒟k▽f​(𝒘n−1;𝒙k​i,yk​i),subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛▽subscript𝒘𝑛1𝜂subscript𝐷𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘𝑓subscript𝒘𝑛1subscript𝒙𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\bm{w}_{k,n}=\bm{w}_{n-1}-\frac{\eta}{D_{k}}\sum_{(x_{ki},y_{ki})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\bigtriangledown f(\bm{w}_{n-1};\bm{x}_{ki},y_{ki}), (4)

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate and ▽f​(𝒘n−1;𝒙k​i,yk​i)▽𝑓subscript𝒘𝑛1subscript𝒙𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\bigtriangledown f(\bm{w}_{n-1};\bm{x}_{ki},y_{ki}) is the gradient of f​(𝒘;𝒙k​i,yk​i)𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖f(\bm{w};\bm{x}_{ki},y_{ki}) with respect to 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} at 𝒘n−1subscript𝒘𝑛1\bm{w}_{n-1}.

After all scheduled devices upload their local models, the UAV aggregates them to obtain the following consolidated global model

𝒘n=∑k=1Kak​[n]​𝒘k,n∑k=1Kak​[n],subscript𝒘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\bm{w}_{n}=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{K}a_{k}[n]\bm{w}_{k,n}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}a_{k}[n]}, (5)

where 𝒘nsubscript𝒘𝑛\bm{w}_{n} is the global model updated at the UAV in the n𝑛n-th round. With (4) and (5), the UAV and the devices can repeatedly update their models until the maximum number of communication rounds reaches. As the local FL models are updated at the scheduled devices and transmitted over wireless cellular links, device scheduling determines both the learning performance and communication delay. Furthermore, the channel conditions between the UAV and devices vary over different time slots due to the mobility of the UAV. Hence, device scheduling should be optimized along with the time allocation and UAV trajectory to account for time-varying channel conditions and the target convergence accuracy required of FL. In the next subsection, we elaborate on the communication and computation models of FL over UAV-enabled networks.

II-B UAV-enabled Transmission

Without loss of generality, we consider a three-dimensional (3D) Cartesian coordinate. Each ground device is fixed to the ground. The horizontal coordinate of ground device k𝑘k is denoted as 𝐮k=[x~k,y~k]∈ℝ1×2subscript𝐮𝑘subscript~𝑥𝑘subscript~𝑦𝑘superscriptℝ12\mathbf{u}_{k}=[\tilde{x}_{k},\tilde{y}_{k}]\in\mathbb{R}^{1\times 2} with x~ksubscript~𝑥𝑘\tilde{x}_{k} and y~ksubscript~𝑦𝑘\tilde{y}_{k} being x𝑥x- and y𝑦y-coordinates, respectively. We assume each ground device is known from the UAV, which flies at a fixed height H𝐻H m above the ground. In practice, H𝐻H corresponds to the minimum altitude at which obstacles can be avoided without needing frequent aircraft ascended and descended.

In this paper, we suppose that the total number of communication rounds denoted by N𝑁N is fixed. We focus on the time required for the UAV to complete the FL process, wherein the corresponding variable is denoted as T𝑇T. To facilitate trajectory design, we adopt the time-discretization technique to divide the mission duration T𝑇T into N𝑁N unequal time slots, wherein the n𝑛n-th slot duration is expressed as δ​[n]𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\delta[n] with ∑n=1Nδ​[n]=Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁𝛿delimited-[]𝑛𝑇\sum_{n=1}^{N}\delta[n]=T. Note that {δ​[n]}𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\{\delta[n]\} and T𝑇T are variables in this paper. We denote the location of the UAV at time slot n𝑛n projected on the horizontal (ground) plane as 𝒒​[n]=[x​[n],y​[n]]∈ℝ1×2𝒒delimited-[]𝑛𝑥delimited-[]𝑛𝑦delimited-[]𝑛superscriptℝ12\bm{q}[n]=[x[n],y[n]]\in\mathbb{R}^{1\times 2}, with x​[n]𝑥delimited-[]𝑛x[n] and y​[n]𝑦delimited-[]𝑛y[n] being x𝑥x- and y𝑦y-coordinates at time slot n𝑛n, respectively. In addition, we consider the scenario where the initial location of the UAV is pre-deployed, the horizontal coordinate of which is denoted as 𝒒F=[xF,yF]∈ℝ1×2subscript𝒒𝐹subscript𝑥𝐹subscript𝑦𝐹superscriptℝ12\bm{q}_{F}=[x_{F},y_{F}]\in\mathbb{R}^{1\times 2}. This is because the initial location corresponds to the practical mobility constraint on the UAV such as the UAV’s launching location or its pre-mission flying paths, etc. We assume that the link between each device and the UAV is dominated by the LoS channel because UAVs usually fly at high altitudes for safety reasons, as most existing studies on UAVs [30, 31, 21]. Following the free-space path loss model [30], the channel gain between device k𝑘k and the UAV at time slot n𝑛n is given by

hk​[n]=β0​dk−2​[n]=β0H2+‖𝒒​[n]−𝐮k‖22,subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝛽0superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘2delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝛽0superscript𝐻2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒒delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝐮𝑘22\displaystyle{h}_{k}[n]=\beta_{0}d_{k}^{-2}[n]=\frac{\beta_{0}}{{H^{2}+\|\bm{q}[n]-\mathbf{u}_{k}\|_{2}^{2}}}, (6)

where β0subscript𝛽0\beta_{0} represents the channel gain at the reference distance of 1 meter and dk​[n]subscript𝑑𝑘delimited-[]𝑛d_{k}[n] is the distance between device k𝑘k and the UAV at time slot n𝑛n.

The distance moved by the UAV in the n𝑛n-th slot is subject to the following constraint

‖𝒒​[n]−𝒒​[n−1]‖2≤min⁡{Vmax​δ​[n],Δ​qmax},n=1,…,N,formulae-sequencesubscriptnorm𝒒delimited-[]𝑛𝒒delimited-[]𝑛12subscript𝑉𝛿delimited-[]𝑛Δsubscript𝑞𝑛1…𝑁\displaystyle\|\bm{q}[n]\!-\!\bm{q}[n-1]\|_{2}\!\leq\!\min\{V_{\max}\delta[n],\Delta q_{\max}\},n=1,\ldots,N, (7)

where Vmaxsubscript𝑉V_{\max} is the maximum UAV speed, and Δ​qmaxΔsubscript𝑞\Delta q_{\max} is an appropriately chosen value with Δ​qmax≪Hmuch-less-thanΔsubscript𝑞𝐻\Delta q_{\max}\ll H such that channel gain during each round is assumed to be unchanged.

Each time interval δ​[n]𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\delta[n] consists of four stages, namely, the local computation stage, the local model uploading stage, the global computation stage, and the global model downloading stage, as shown in Fig. 1.

II-B1 Local Computation

We denote the required number of processing cycles for computing one data sample at device k𝑘k by cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k}, which can be measured offline and is known as a prior. Since all samples {𝒙k​i,yk​i}i∈𝒟ksubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘\{\bm{x}_{ki},y_{ki}\}_{i\in\mathcal{D}_{k}} have the same size (i.e., number of bits), the number of CPU cycles required for device k𝑘k to run one local round is ck​Dksubscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘c_{k}D_{k}. By denoting the CPU-cycle frequency of the device k𝑘k by fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}, the computation time per round of device k𝑘k is given by

tkcomp=ck​Dkfk.superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘compsubscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘\displaystyle t_{k}^{\text{comp}}=\frac{c_{k}D_{k}}{f_{k}}. (8)

The CPU energy consumption of device k𝑘k for the n𝑛n-th round of local computation is [22]

Ekcomp​[n]=ak​[n]​∑i=1ck​Dkαk2​fk2=ak​[n]​αk2​ck​Dk​fk2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘compdelimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘2subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝛼𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘2\displaystyle E_{k}^{\text{comp}}[n]=a_{k}[n]\sum_{i=1}^{c_{k}D_{k}}\frac{\alpha_{k}}{2}f_{k}^{2}=a_{k}[n]\frac{\alpha_{k}}{2}c_{k}D_{k}f_{k}^{2}, (9)

where αk/2subscript𝛼𝑘2\alpha_{k}/2 is the effective capacitance coefficient of device k𝑘k’s computing chipset. Similar to [22], we consider the synchronous operation that requires all scheduled devices to simultaneously train their local models and complete their training before entering the communication phase. Thus, the time cost for local model training at the n𝑛n-th round is given by [22]

tcomp​[n]=maxk⁡{ak​[n]​tkcomp}.superscript𝑡compdelimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘comp\displaystyle t^{\text{comp}}[n]=\max_{k}\{a_{k}[n]t_{k}^{\text{comp}}\}. (10)

Hence, the computing time in one local round is determined by scheduled devices with large date sizes and low CPU frequency.

II-B2 Local Model Uploading

In the local model uploading stage, to avoid interference among devices during the uploading process, TDMA [22] is adopted as shown in Fig. 1. Specifically, in the local model uploading stage, |𝒜n|subscript𝒜𝑛|\mathcal{A}_{n}| devices send their respective local models one by one during slot n𝑛n. The achievable data rate (bit/s) of devices k𝑘k at the n𝑛n-th round is defined as

rk​[n]=B​log2⁡(1+pk​[n]​hk​[n]σ2),subscript𝑟𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝑝𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝜎2\displaystyle r_{k}[n]=B\log_{2}\Big{(}1+\frac{p_{k}[n]h_{k}[n]}{\sigma^{2}}\Big{)}, (11)

where B𝐵B is the system bandwidth in Hertz, pk​[n]subscript𝑝𝑘delimited-[]𝑛p_{k}[n] is the transmit power of device k𝑘k at the n𝑛n-th round, and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the power of the additional complex Gaussian noise. Let τk​[n]subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛\tau_{k}[n] denote the duration in which device k𝑘k transmits its local model to the UAV at the n𝑛n-th round. We assume that the dimension of the model parameter vector is fixed throughout the FL process, denoted by s𝑠s (in bits). The uploading time of device k𝑘k can be calculated as

τk​[n]=ak​[n]​srk​[n].subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠subscript𝑟𝑘delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\tau_{k}[n]=\frac{a_{k}[n]s}{r_{k}[n]}. (12)

With a given data size, the larger the channel gain, the shorter the required uploading time. The UAV can shorten the uploading time of scheduled devices by establishing LoS connections and shortening communication distances with the devices. By combining (11) and (12), to transmit s𝑠s within a time duration τk​[n]subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛\tau_{k}[n], the device k𝑘k’s energy consumption is

Ekcomm​[n]=τk​[n]​σ2hk​[n]​(2ak​[n]​sB​τk​[n]−1).superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘commdelimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝜎2subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript2subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1\displaystyle E_{k}^{\text{comm}}[n]=\frac{\tau_{k}[n]\sigma^{2}}{h_{k}[n]}\Big{(}2^{\frac{a_{k}[n]s}{B\tau_{k}[n]}}-1\Big{)}. (13)

After all scheduled devices upload their local training models {𝒘k,n}subscript𝒘𝑘𝑛\{\bm{w}_{k,n}\} at the n𝑛n-th slot, the UAV performs the global model update and broadcasts the updated result of length s𝑠s bits to the devices. Let f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} denote the UAV processor’s fixed computing speed, c0subscript𝑐0c_{0} denote the required number of processing cycles for one local model at the UAV, and P0subscript𝑃0P_{0} denote the transmit power of the UAV. The time that spent on updating global model and feeding the result back to devices at the UAV is expressed as

tUAV​[n]=K​c0f0+smink∈𝒜n⁡B​log2⁡(1+P0​hk​[n]σ2).superscript𝑡UAVdelimited-[]𝑛𝐾subscript𝑐0subscript𝑓0𝑠subscript𝑘subscript𝒜𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃0subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝜎2\displaystyle t^{\text{UAV}}[n]=\frac{Kc_{0}}{f_{0}}+\frac{s}{\min_{k\in\mathcal{A}_{n}}B\log_{2}\Big{(}1+\frac{P_{0}h_{k}[n]}{\sigma^{2}}\Big{)}}. (14)

One aspect, comparing to the time of local model computation at any device k𝑘k denoting Dk​ckfksubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘\frac{D_{k}c_{k}}{f_{k}}, the first term in (14) is negligible. The reasons are that the UAV has a higher computation capability f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} than that of the devices fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} [31]. Moreover, the number of devices K𝐾K is much smaller than the size of the local dataset Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. The other aspect, the UAV only needs to broadcast the global model to devices while all the scheduled devices upload their local models via TDMA. Accordingly, we can infer that tUAV​[n]≪∑k=1Kτk​[n]+tcomp​[n]much-less-thansuperscript𝑡UAVdelimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝑡compdelimited-[]𝑛t^{\text{UAV}}[n]\ll\sum_{k=1}^{K}\tau_{k}[n]+t^{\text{comp}}[n], and the global computation time and the global model downloading time at the UAV are neglected as in [22], [31]. Thus, the total uploading time of devices can occupy the rest of the time after local model training at the n𝑛n-th round, i.e.,

∑k=1Kτk​[n]≤δ​[n]−tcomp​[n],∀n.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝛿delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝑡compdelimited-[]𝑛for-all𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\tau_{k}[n]\leq\delta[n]-t^{\text{comp}}[n],\forall n. (15)

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Formulation

In this section, we conduct the convergence analysis of UAV-enabled FL, which characterizes the impact of key system parameters on the convergence performance, and then formulate a completion time minimization problem, taking into account communication resource constraints, UAV deployment constraints, and target convergence accuracy of FL.

III-A Convergence Analysis of FL

We follow the literature and make two standard assumptions on the loss function and local gradients as follows [32, 33, 34, 35, 16, 36, 37].

Assumption 1.

(Smoothness). The function ℱℱ\mathcal{F}: ℝd→ℝ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is L𝐿L-smooth. That is, ∀𝒘,𝒘′∈ℝdfor-all𝒘superscript𝒘′superscriptℝ𝑑\forall\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

ℱ​(𝒘)≤ℱ​(𝒘′)+⟨∇ℱ​(𝒘′),𝒘−𝒘′⟩+L2​‖𝒘′−𝒘‖22.ℱ𝒘ℱsuperscript𝒘′∇ℱsuperscript𝒘′𝒘superscript𝒘′𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒘′𝒘22\displaystyle\!\!\mathcal{F}(\bm{w})\leq\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}^{\prime})+\langle\nabla\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}^{\prime}),\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\|\bm{w}^{\prime}-\bm{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (16)

And the loss function does not have to satisfy the convexity assumption, and only needs to be lower-bounded, which is the minimal assumption required for convergence [34, 35].

Assumption 2.

(Bounded Loss Function). For any parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, the loss function ℱ​(𝒘)ℱ𝒘\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}) is lower-bounded by F⋆superscript𝐹⋆F^{\star}.

The following assumption is also standard in the literature [16, 36, 37].

Assumption 3.

(Bounded Sample-wise Gradient Norm). For a constant κ>0𝜅0\kappa>0, the sample-wise gradients at local devices are bounded

‖∇f​(𝒘n;𝒙,y)‖22≤κ.superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝒘𝑛𝒙𝑦22𝜅\displaystyle\|\nabla f(\bm{w}_{n};\bm{x},y)\|_{2}^{2}\leq\kappa. (17)

We use the average gradient norm as an indicator of convergence for FL, which is widely adopted in the convergence analysis for non-convex loss function [38, 32]. According to the above assumptions, the average gradient norm can be bound, explained as follows.

Theorem 1.

Suppose that the loss functions satisfy assumptions 1-3, given the learning rate 0≤η≤1L0𝜂1𝐿0\leq\eta\leq\frac{1}{L}, after N𝑁N rounds, the average norm of the global gradients is upper bounded by

1N​∑n=0N−1‖∇ℱ​(𝒘n)‖21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁1superscriptnorm∇ℱsubscript𝒘𝑛2\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\|\nabla\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{n})\|^{2} ≤\displaystyle\leq 2N​η​(ℱ​(𝒘0)−F⋆)+4​K​κN​D2​∑n=0N−1∑k=1K(1−ak​[n+1])​Dk2.2𝑁𝜂ℱsubscript𝒘0superscript𝐹⋆4𝐾𝜅𝑁superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘2\displaystyle\frac{2}{N\eta}(\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{0})-F^{\star})+\frac{4K\kappa}{ND^{2}}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(1-a_{k}[n+1])D_{k}^{2}. (18)

Given rounds N𝑁N, the FL algorithm achieves an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximation solution if [32]

1N​∑n=0N−1‖∇ℱ​(𝒘n)‖22≤ϵ,1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁1superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℱsubscript𝒘𝑛22italic-ϵ\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\|\nabla\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{n})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\epsilon, (19)

where ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 is the convergence threshold.

Remark 1.

As we can see, the expression (18) comprises two terms. The first term is the initial optimality gap. For the first term, when the number of communication rounds, the learning step-size, and the initial model parameter are given, the initial optimality gap is a constant. The second term is the time-average aggregation error resulting from the effect of device scheduling. For the second term, the time-average aggregation error decreases as the number of scheduled devices increases, particularly when large data-size devices are scheduled. However, scheduling more devices in one round for model uploading increases the communication burden and may significantly slow down the model aggregation process, especially if there are communication stragglers. Thus, it is crucial to schedule a proper subset of devices to balance training performance and time consumption.

III-B Problem Formulation

Let 𝑨={ak[n],∀n∈𝒩,∀k∈𝒦}\bm{A}=\{a_{k}[n],\forall n\in\mathcal{N},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}\}, 𝚪={τk[n],∀n∈𝒩,∀k∈𝒦}\bm{\Gamma}=\{\tau_{k}[n],\forall n\in\mathcal{N},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}\}, 𝑸={𝒒[n],∀n=0,…,N}\bm{Q}=\{\bm{q}[n],\forall n=0,\ldots,N\}, and 𝜹={δ[n],∀n=1,…,N}\bm{\delta}=\{\delta[n],\forall n=1,\ldots,N\}. In this paper, given the number of communication rounds N𝑁N, we aim to minimize the completion time of the FL training process under the target convergence accuracy requirements by jointly optimizing the devices’ scheduling variables 𝑨𝑨\bm{A}, time allocation 𝚪𝚪\bm{\Gamma}, UAV trajectory 𝑸𝑸\bm{Q}, and slot intervals 𝜹𝜹\bm{\delta}. To satisfy the convergence requirement in (19), we ensure that the upper bound in Theorem 1 is less than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Therefore, the corresponding optimization problem is formulated as

minimize𝑨,𝚪,𝑸,𝜹subscriptminimize𝑨𝚪𝑸𝜹\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\mathop{\text{minimize}}_{\bm{A},\bm{\Gamma},\bm{Q},\bm{\delta}} ∑n=1Nδ​[n]superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}\delta[n]
subject to ak​[n]∈{0,1},∀k∈𝒦,∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛01formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑛𝒩\displaystyle a_{k}[n]\in\{0,1\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, (20f)
∑n=1N(Ekcomm​[n]+Ekcomp​[n])≤Ek,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘commdelimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘compdelimited-[]𝑛subscript𝐸𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}\Big{(}E_{k}^{\text{comm}}[n]+E_{k}^{\text{comp}}[n]\Big{)}\leq{E}_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},
∑k=1Kτk​[n]+maxk⁡ak​[n]​tkcomp≤δ​[n],∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘comp𝛿delimited-[]𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\tau_{k}[n]\!+\!\max_{k}a_{k}[n]t_{k}^{\text{comp}}\leq\delta[n],\forall n\in\mathcal{N},
2N​η​(ℱ​(𝒘0)−F⋆)+4​K​κN​D2​∑n=0N−1∑k=1K(1−ak​[n+1])​Dk2≤ϵ,2𝑁𝜂ℱsubscript𝒘0superscript𝐹⋆4𝐾𝜅𝑁superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘2italic-ϵ\displaystyle\frac{2}{N\eta}(\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{0})-F^{\star})+\frac{4K\kappa}{ND^{2}}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(1-a_{k}[n+1])D_{k}^{2}\leq\epsilon,
𝒒​[0]=𝒒F,𝒒delimited-[]0subscript𝒒𝐹\displaystyle\bm{q}[0]=\bm{q}_{F},
Constraints​(​7​).Constraintsitalic-(7italic-)\displaystyle\text{Constraints}~{}\eqref{Cons:Q distance}.

Constraints (20f) are integer constraints with respect to the devices’ scheduling variables. Constraints (20f) represent the devices’ energy budgets. Constraints (20f) ensure that the communication and computation time per round cannot exceed the duration of each time slot. Constraint (20f) denotes the target convergence accuracy requirement of FL. Constraint (20f) is subject to the initial location of the UAV. Problem (20) is challenging to solve due to the following reasons. First, the optimization variables 𝑨𝑨\bm{A} for device scheduling are binary and thus (20f)-(20f) involve integer constraints. Second, Ekcomm​[n]superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘commdelimited-[]𝑛E_{k}^{\text{comm}}[n] in constraints (20f) are not jointly convex with respect to the optimization variables 𝑨,𝚪,𝑸𝑨𝚪𝑸\bm{A},\bm{\Gamma},\bm{Q}, and 𝜹𝜹\bm{\delta}. Therefore, problem (20) is a mixed-integer non-convex problem, which is difficult to be optimally solved in general.

III-C Problem Analysis

In this subsection, we take a close look at problem (20) and compare our formulation with those in the existing literature. Furthermore, we discuss properties of the considered problem formulation and emphasize the necessity of introducing flying UAVs into the FL system.

The existing works on wireless FL with static terrestrial BS [39, 11, 23] have made attempts to minimize the completion time under the convergence accuracy requirements by optimizing device scheduling. Comparing our proposed formulation with the frameworks in [39, 11, 23], the following differences can be seen:

  • •

    Problem (20) not only considers the learning and adaptive device scheduling, but also takes into account the practical device’s energy budget and dynamic channel conditions. Conversely, [39, 11], and [23] do not study these practical communication issues.

  • •

    Given the number of communication rounds, problem (20) explicitly integrates the target convergence accuracy requirement (i.e., constraint (20f)) into the completion time minimization. In contrast, the formulated problems in [39, 11] do not directly show the relationship between learning convergence accuracy and the completion time.

Prior to solving problem (20), we should check its feasibility. According to (18), when all devices are scheduled in every communication round, the convergence bound reaches the minimum value. Therefore, if the minimum value of the convergence bound is larger than the target convergence accuracy, problem (20) is infeasible. Moreover, if Ek,∀ksubscript𝐸𝑘for-all𝑘E_{k},\forall k is not big enough, the constraints in (20f) may not be satisfied even though the scheduled devices consume the lowest amount of energy. To sum up, the following proposition is given to check the feasibility of problem (20).

Proposition 1.

Problem (20) is feasible if and only if

N≥⌈2​(ℱ​(𝒘0)−F⋆)ϵ​η⌉​ and ​∑k=1KEk≥|𝒮|​σ2​s​H2​ln⁡2β0​B,𝑁2ℱsubscript𝒘0superscript𝐹⋆italic-ϵ𝜂 and superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐸𝑘𝒮superscript𝜎2𝑠superscript𝐻22subscript𝛽0𝐵\displaystyle N\geq\lceil\frac{2(\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{0})-F^{\star})}{\epsilon\eta}\rceil\text{~{}and~{}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}E_{k}\geq|\mathcal{S}|\frac{\sigma^{2}sH^{2}\ln 2}{\beta_{0}B}, (21)

where |𝒮|𝒮|\mathcal{S}| denotes the required amount of scheduled devices during training process, given by |𝒮|=⌈K​N−(ϵ−2N​η​(ℱ​(𝒘0)−F⋆))​N​D24​K​κ​maxk⁡Dk2⌉.𝒮𝐾𝑁italic-ϵ2𝑁𝜂ℱsubscript𝒘0superscript𝐹⋆𝑁superscript𝐷24𝐾𝜅subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘2|\mathcal{S}|=\lceil KN-(\epsilon-\frac{2}{N\eta}(\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{0})-F^{\star}))\frac{ND^{2}}{4K\kappa\max_{k}D_{k}^{2}}\rceil.

Proof.

Please refer to Appendix -B. ∎

We show the effect of the target convergence accuracy of FL on the completion time.

Theorem 2.

For problem (20), the objective value is non-increasing with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

Proof.

Please refer to Appendix -C. ∎

Theorem 2 sheds light on the tradeoff between the completion time of FL and the target convergence accuracy of FL due to the limited energy budgets. This is because imposing more stringent convergence accuracy requirements increases the required amount of scheduled devices in the FL training process, which can be observed from constraint (20f). From (20), we see that time used for the update of the local models depends on the device scheduling matrix 𝑨𝑨\bm{A} and UAV trajectory 𝑸𝑸\bm{Q}. Fortunately, by exploiting the UAV’s mobility, UAV can dynamically establish favorable connections with scheduled devices in each round to mitigate the communication straggler issue, thereby reducing the completion time of the FL.

IV Device Scheduling and Time allocation along with Trajectory Design

In this section, we present the BCD-LD method to design the device scheduling, time allocation, and UAV trajectory. Specifically, we first optimize the device scheduling and time allocation for a given UAV trajectory. Given device scheduling and time allocation solutions, we then optimize the UAV trajectory 𝑸𝑸\bm{Q}. To avoid the high computational complexity, we also use LD methods to derive the optimal and closed-form solutions for each optimization subproblem.

IV-A Joint Device Scheduling and Time Allocation

Remark 2.

Theorem 4 shows that the dual method obtains the binary solution for device scheduling variables, which guarantees both optimality and feasibility of the original problem. It would also make sense to select a device with a large data-set, a large channel gain, and a high computation capacity.

Nevertheless, with the above proposed solutions to problems (IV-A) and (IV-A), the dual function g​(𝝀,𝝁,ξ)𝑔𝝀𝝁𝜉g(\bm{\lambda},\bm{\mu},\xi) is obtained.

The dual problem (27) can be solved after obtaining (𝝉⋆,𝜹⋆,𝑨⋆)superscript𝝉⋆superscript𝜹⋆superscript𝑨⋆(\bm{\tau}^{\star},\bm{\delta}^{\star},\bm{A}^{\star}). Despite the fact that the dual function g​(𝝀,𝝁,ξ)𝑔𝝀𝝁𝜉g(\bm{\lambda},\bm{\mu},\xi) is always convex by definition, it is generally non-differentiable. To address this challenge, a common subgradient-based method, such as projected subgradient decent method, can be applied to solving the (27). Specifically, dual variables are updated in each iteration via

Based on 𝝀⋆superscript𝝀⋆\bm{\lambda}^{\star}, 𝝁⋆superscript𝝁⋆\bm{\mu}^{\star}, and ξ⋆superscript𝜉⋆\xi^{\star} have been obtained, it is left to find the optimal primal solution {𝜹⋆,𝝉⋆,𝑨⋆}superscript𝜹⋆superscript𝝉⋆superscript𝑨⋆\{\bm{\delta}^{\star},\bm{\tau}^{\star},\bm{A}^{\star}\} of problem (25). For a convex optimization problem, a solution that minimizes the Lagrange function is optimal only if it is unique and primal feasible. Unfortunately, in this case, the solutions 𝜹𝜹\bm{\delta} that minimizes ℒ​(𝜹,𝑨,𝝉,𝝀,𝝁,ξ)ℒ𝜹𝑨𝝉𝝀𝝁𝜉\mathcal{L}(\bm{\delta},\bm{A},\bm{\tau},\bm{\lambda},\bm{\mu},\xi) are not unique when ∑k=1Kμk​[n]≤1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mu_{k}[n]\leq 1. To construct the optimal solution, additional steps are needed. Specifically, given 𝝀⋆superscript𝝀⋆\bm{\lambda}^{\star}, 𝝁⋆superscript𝝁⋆\bm{\mu}^{\star}, and ξ⋆superscript𝜉⋆\xi^{\star}, the optimal time allocation (i.e., 𝝉⋆superscript𝝉⋆\bm{\tau}^{\star}) and device scheduling variable (i.e., 𝑨⋆superscript𝑨⋆\bm{A}^{\star}) can be uniquely obtained by (30) and (32), respectively. Algorithm 2 summarizes the details of obtaining the optimal solution to problem (25). Algorithm 2 includes three parts, i.e., solving problems (IV-A) and (IV-A), updating the dual variables, and solving problem (38). According to (30) and (32), the complexity of solving problem (IV-A) is 𝒪​(K​N)𝒪𝐾𝑁\mathcal{O}(KN). According to (34) and (39), the complexity of both solving problem (IV-A) and problem (38) is 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N). In addition, according to (36)-(35), the complexity of updating the dual variables is 𝒪​(K​N)𝒪𝐾𝑁\mathcal{O}(KN). Denote by l1subscript𝑙1l_{1} the number of iterations required for convergence. Therefore, the total complexity of Algorithm 2 is given by 𝒪​(l1​K​N)𝒪subscript𝑙1𝐾𝑁\mathcal{O}(l_{1}KN).

Although the convex QCQP problem (41) can be solved using a general-purpose solver through interior-point methods, to further reduce the computational complexity, we exploit the specific structure of problem (41) and find its optimal solution by using a Lagrange dual ascent method in the sequel. As the strong duality holds, we can solve problem (41) by equivalently solving its dual problem (44). Theorem 5.

The procedure for solving problem (41) is similar to that of solving problem (25). The details are omitted due to space limitations.

IV-C Overall Algorithm Design

In this section, based on the results in previous two subsections, we present an efficient iterative algorithm to solve problem (20) by using the BCD technique [40], which is summarized in Algorithm 3. Note that the subproblem for updating each block of variables is solved with optimality in each iteration. The convergence of Algorithm 3 is shown in the following proposition.

Proposition 2.

With Algorithm 3, the objective value of problem (20) decreases as the number of iterations increases until convergence.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we present extensive numerical results to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm for FL via UAV. We consider the image classification task on the widely-used CIFAR-10 datasets [41], which is composed of 60, 000 32×32323232\times 32 RGB color images in 10 different classes. We adopt the multi-nominal logistic regression model to classify the target datasets with features d=32×32×3×10𝑑3232310d=32\times 32\times 3\times 10 and leaning rate η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01. And the loss function is

ℱk​(𝒘)=−1Dk​∑i=1Dk∑c=1101{yi=c}​log⁡exp​(𝒙i𝖳​𝒘c)∑j=110exp​(𝒙i𝖳​𝒘j).subscriptℱ𝑘𝒘1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐110subscript1subscript𝑦𝑖𝑐expsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝖳subscript𝒘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑗110expsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝖳subscript𝒘𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{F}_{k}(\bm{w})=\frac{-1}{D_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{D_{k}}\sum_{c=1}^{10}1_{\{y_{i}=c\}}\log\frac{\text{exp}(\bm{x}_{i}^{\sf T}\bm{w}_{c})}{\sum_{j=1}^{10}\text{exp}(\bm{x}_{i}^{\sf T}\bm{w}_{j})}. (47)

Each parameter is assumed to be stored with I=32𝐼32I=32 bits, i.e., s=I×d𝑠𝐼𝑑s=I\times d. The effective capacitance coefficient of all devices’ computing chipset is α1=…=αk=10−28subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑘superscript1028\alpha_{1}=\ldots=\alpha_{k}=10^{-28}. The local training data are uniformly drawn from 50,000 images with {Dk}subscript𝐷𝑘\{D_{k}\}, and the test dataset contains the remaining 10,000 images. Considering different numbers of training samples, the values of {Dk}subscript𝐷𝑘\{D_{k}\} are drawn uniformly. In the simulations, the service area of the UAV is restricted to a square area with the size of [0, 400] m ×\times [0, 400] m. The UAV is assumed to fly at a fixed altitude of H=100𝐻100H=100 m, which complies with the practical rule, i.e., commercial UAVs should not fly over 400 feet (122 m) [42]. And the UAV is placed at a predetermined initial position, i.e., (200, 0, 100) m. The maximum speed of the UAV is Vmax=20subscript𝑉20{V}_{\max}=20 m/s. In addition, considering channel heterogeneity, K𝐾K devices are separated into two clusters allocated in two circles, i.e., cluster A𝐴A with ⌊0.3​K⌋0.3𝐾\lfloor 0.3K\rfloor devices and cluster B𝐵B with K−⌊0.3​K⌋𝐾0.3𝐾K-\lfloor 0.3K\rfloor devices. Specifically, the devices in cluster A𝐴A and cluster B𝐵B are randomly and uniformly distributed in circles centered at (100, 100) m and (300, 300) m with a radius of 100 m, respectively. Other parameters are summarized in Table I.

We compare the performance of the proposed joint design scheme with the following schemes: 1) Static UAV: With this scheme, the UAV is placed at a predetermined initial position, i.e., (200, 0, 100) m, and remains static during the whole mission time. This scheme optimizes {𝑨,𝝉,𝜹}𝑨𝝉𝜹\{\bm{A},\bm{\tau},\bm{\delta}\} to minimize the completion time for FL by solving problem (25), as presented in Algorithm 2. 2) Static UAV w/ HS: In this scheme, the UAV is static and placed at a predetermined initial position. With the static UAV, the channel conditions of devices are known and invariant. According to the channel-aware criterion [12], the devices with bigger channel gains are always scheduled to satisfy constraint (20f) with equality. Therefore, in this scheme, 𝑨𝑨\bm{A} and 𝑸𝑸\bm{Q} are deterministic, and we only need to optimize {𝝉,𝜹}𝝉𝜹\{\bm{\tau},\bm{\delta}\} to minimize the completion time for FL. 3) Full Scheduling: This scheme schedules all devices to upload in every communication round. And without model aggregation loss resulting from device scheduling, this scheme achieves the minimum convergence accuracy of FL, which serves as a performance bound for other schemes. By substituting the given 𝑨𝑨\bm{A} into problem (20), this scheme optimizes {𝝉,𝜹,𝑸}𝝉𝜹𝑸\{\bm{\tau},\bm{\delta},\bm{Q}\} to minimize the completion time for FL. We still adopt the BCD-based iterative algorithm to solve the resulting problem, which is similar to Algorithm 3.

V-A Optimized UAV Trajectory

Fig. 4 shows the convergence behaviors of the proposed BCD-based algorithm (i.e., Algorithm 3) with different device energy budgets Eksubscript𝐸𝑘E_{k}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k when ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2. All devices have the same energy budgets. It is observed that for both schemes, the completion time with Algorithm 3 decreases quickly with the number of iterations, and the two algorithms converge within 5 iterations with prescribed accuracy ε=10−3𝜀superscript103\varepsilon=10^{-3}. Besides, the proposed joint design achieves a smaller completion time under Ek=30subscript𝐸𝑘30E_{k}=30 J compared to Ek=10subscript𝐸𝑘10E_{k}=10 J.

Fig. 4 illustrates the trajectories obtained by Algorithm 3 under different convergence accuracy of FL ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Each trajectory is sampled every 5 rounds and the sampled points are marked with △△\triangle by using the same colors as their corresponding trajectories. The devices’ locations are marked by a dark blue □□\square. The predetermined locations of the UAV are red ⋆⋆\star. We can observe that with different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the optimized trajectories have some similar behaviors. First, the UAV visits the devices in both clusters as close as possible along an arc path, which means the UAV proactively shortens the devices’ communication distance and thus schedules different devices to participate in FL training. We also observe that the densities of sampling points on the trajectory in different time slots are different. As a result of varying channel coefficients, the selected devices change during training.

To unveil the phenomena in trajectories obtained by these algorithms and the reasons for such phenomena, we plot the corresponding UAV speed and the percentage of scheduled devices over communication rounds, as shown in Fig. 4. It can be observed that there are three stages for behaviors of scheduled devices. Furthermore, the behaviors of the corresponding UAV speed are consistent with that of the percentage of scheduled devices. In the following, we elaborate on these three stages.

  • •

    Stage I: As shown in Fig. 4, from round 1 to about 1300 rounds, the percentage of participating devices per round is equal to 0, which means that no device is involved in FL training during this time interval. This is because in this interval when the UAV stays in the initial position, the communication straggler issue is severe.

  • •

    Stage II: From about 1300 to 1400 rounds, the percentage of participating devices is dynamically changing, which means our proposed design outputs different device selection decisions when the channels change.

  • •

    Stage III: From about 1400 rounds to 4000 rounds, the percentage of participating devices equals 100%percent100100\% in each round, which means with the synergy of trajectory and energy, the optimized device scheduling not only satisfies the convergence accuracy but also maximizes data exploitation, thereby reducing model aggregation loss and accelerating FL convergence.

Importantly note that the effective communication rounds of FL in the proposed scheme only need about 2700 rounds to satisfy the convergence accuracy condition, i.e., ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2.

V-B Performance Comparison for Completion Time

Fig. 6 shows the effect of the convergence accuracy of FL on the completion time when E=10𝐸10E=10 J. Since the full scheduling scheme does not result in the model aggregation loss, its performance is invariant to the convergence accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. However, this scheme costs prohibitive completion time without device scheduling. Note that this scheme may be forbidden in general since UAVs usually have a limited endurance due to practical physical constraints (e.g., 30 minutes for the typical rotary-wing UAV [30]). For the other three schemes with device scheduling, the completion time decreases with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which is consistent with Theorem 2. In addition, the Static UAV scheme has a shorter completion time than the Static UAV w/ HS scheme since the former avoids the aggregation error explosion by excluding the weak devices. However, in the case of strong straggler issues, the performance gain brought by device scheduling optimization alone is very limited. Fortunately, the proposed joint design scheme incorporated trajectory design with device scheduling significantly reduce the completion time compared to all benchmarks. This is because, the mobile UAV can shorten communication distances between the scheduled devices and always achieve a high transmission rate for local model uploading, thereby accelerating the model aggregation process. These results demonstrate in UAV-enabled systems, joint trajectory and device scheduling device is critical to mitigating the communication stragglers’ effect.

Fig. 6 shows the total mission completion time versus the device energy budget when ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2. It is observed that, for all schemes, the total completion time decreases as E𝐸E increases. This is because, as E𝐸E increases, the scheduled devices can afford more energy to upload local models with higher transmission rates. We also find that the proposed joint design achieves the smallest completion time compared to all benchmarks. This observation further verifies the superiority of the proposed scheme to mitigate the stragglers’ effect.

V-C Performance Comparison for FL

To demonstrate the performance of our proposed joint design for dealing with FL tasks, we train image classifier models on the widely-used CIFAR-10 dataset. In the simulations, the full scheduling scheme allows all devices to participate in the training process at each FL round that can achieve the most optimal FL performance, which serves as the lower bound.

Fig. 8 shows training accuracy over communication rounds with different schemes and different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. We can observe that the convergence accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon heavily affects the learning performance of the Static UAV w/ HS since a larger value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon implies that the data are less exploited in this scheme due to the fact of device exclusion. In contrast, the proposed joint design still achieves a training accuracy that is close to the ideal benchmark even as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon increases. For example, we can see from Fig. 4 with ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2, the percentage of participating devices is 100%percent100100\% from about 1400 rounds to 4000 rounds. This is because the proposed joint design scheme overcomes the straggler issue and maximizes data exploitation. Specifically, the UAV’s trajectory tends to be close to the devices to establish strong communication links, thus maximizing data exploitation. In contrast, at some UAV locations (e.g., the initial position), where the communication straggler issue is severe, the device schedule is optimized to let no device be involved in FL training. This is the reason why the curve of the proposed joint design scheme is invariant during the initial communication rounds. On the other hand, by properly designing the trajectory of the UAV, short-distance LoS links can be proactively and dynamically established for any device, which ensures all devices have equal opportunity to participate in FL training instead of device exclusion, thereby increasing the data exploitation and training accuracy.

Fig. 8 shows the test accuracy versus convergence rate of FL constraints with different schemes when E=10𝐸10E=10 J. It is observed that for all schemes except for the full scheduling scheme, the test accuracy decreases as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon increases. Observed from Fig. 6 and Fig. 8, it shows that there exists a fundamental trade-off between the mission completion time and the learning performance of FL. However, by exploiting the mobility of the UAV and flexibility of device scheduling, our proposed joint design significantly improves the trade-off compared to the static UAV w/ HS scheme. For example, when ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2, the completion time of FL achieved by our proposed joint design, static UAV w/HS, and the full scheduling scheme are respectively 930930930 s, and 115011501150 s, 150015001500 s. Meanwhile, when ϵ=0.2italic-ϵ0.2\epsilon=0.2, the test accuracy achieved by our proposed joint design, static UAV w/HS, and the full scheduling scheme are respectively 38.99%percent38.9938.99\% s, and 32.52%percent32.5232.52\% s, and 39.74%percent39.7439.74\%. For static UAV w/HS, compared to the full scheduling scheme, the completion time reduces 23.33%percent23.3323.33\% while the test accuracy reduces 7.22%percent7.227.22\%. Fortunately, for our proposed joint design, compared to the full scheduling scheme, the completion time reduces 38%percent3838\% while the test accuracy only reduces 0.71%percent0.710.71\%.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we studied the UAV-assisted FL system to effectively address the straggler issue by exploiting the UAV’s high altitude and mobility when the terrestrial PS was unavailable. Specifically, a mobile UAV was deployed as a flying PS to exchange model parameters from distributed ground devices and train a shared FL model. We focused on the joint consideration of device scheduling, UAV trajectory, and time allocation to minimize the completion time required for FL to converge to the desired accuracy level. Before proceeding with problem formulation, we first theoretically analyzed the effect of device scheduling on the convergence rate of FL without the assumptions of convexity. We also provided a convergence bound for the average norm of the global gradient. Based on such convergence results, we formulated the completion time minimization problem, taking into account the practical device’s energy budget, UAV’s mobility constraints, and convergence accuracy constraint. Although the formulated problem was non-convex, we exploited its structures to decompose it into two sub-problems, followed by deriving closed-form solutions via the Lagrange dual ascent method. Simulation results demonstrated that our proposed joint design can significantly reduce completion time and enhance the tradeoff between completion time and prediction accuracy compared to the existing benchmarks.

s​σ2​H2​ln⁡2B​β0​∑k=1K∑n=1Nak​[n]𝑠superscript𝜎2superscript𝐻22𝐵subscript𝛽0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\frac{s\sigma^{2}H^{2}\ln 2}{B\beta_{0}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{n=1}^{N}a_{k}[n] ≤\displaystyle\leq ∑k=1K∑n=1N(Ekcomm​[n]+Ekcomp​[n])≤∑k=1KEk.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘commdelimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘compdelimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐸𝑘\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\Big{(}E_{k}^{\text{comm}}[n]+E_{k}^{\text{comp}}[n]\Big{)}\leq\sum_{k=1}^{K}{E}_{k}. (58)

Combining (56) with (58), to make constraints (20f) and constraint (20f) feasible, we have that

s​σ2​H2​ln⁡2B​β0​|𝒮|≤∑k=1KEk,N≥⌈2​(ℱ​(𝒘0)−F⋆)ϵ​η⌉.formulae-sequence𝑠superscript𝜎2superscript𝐻22𝐵subscript𝛽0𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐸𝑘𝑁2ℱsubscript𝒘0superscript𝐹⋆italic-ϵ𝜂\displaystyle\frac{s\sigma^{2}H^{2}\ln 2}{B\beta_{0}}|\mathcal{S}|\leq\sum_{k=1}^{K}{E}_{k},N\geq\lceil\frac{2(\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{0})-F^{\star})}{\epsilon\eta}\rceil. (59)

Thus, this completes the proof.

-C Proof of Theorem 2

Denote the optimal solutions of problem (20) with ϵ⋆superscriptitalic-ϵ⋆\epsilon^{\star} and ϵ^^italic-ϵ\hat{\epsilon} by with ℰ⋆={𝑨⋆,𝚪⋆,𝑸⋆,𝜹⋆}superscriptℰ⋆superscript𝑨⋆superscript𝚪⋆superscript𝑸⋆superscript𝜹⋆\mathcal{E}^{\star}=\{\bm{A}^{\star},\bm{\Gamma}^{\star},\bm{Q}^{\star},\bm{\delta}^{\star}\} and ℰ^={𝑨^,𝚪^,𝑸^,𝜹^}^ℰbold-^𝑨bold-^𝚪bold-^𝑸bold-^𝜹\hat{\mathcal{E}}=\{\bm{\hat{A}},\bm{\hat{\Gamma}},\bm{\hat{Q}},\bm{\hat{\delta}}\}, respectively. To prove Theorem 2, we only need to show that ∑δ⋆​[n]≥∑δ^​[n]superscript𝛿⋆delimited-[]𝑛^𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\sum\delta^{\star}[n]\geq\sum\hat{\delta}[n] holds when ϵ⋆≤ϵ^superscriptitalic-ϵ⋆^italic-ϵ\epsilon^{\star}\leq\hat{\epsilon}. Note that in problem (20), the convergence threshold is only involved in constraint (20f). Thus, we have the following inequalities

2N​η​(ℱ​(𝒘0)−F⋆)+4​K​κN​D2​∑n=0N−1∑k=1K(1−ak⋆​[n+1])​Dk2≤ϵ⋆≤ϵ^,2𝑁𝜂ℱsubscript𝒘0superscript𝐹⋆4𝐾𝜅𝑁superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘⋆delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘2superscriptitalic-ϵ⋆^italic-ϵ\displaystyle\frac{2}{N\eta}(\mathcal{F}(\bm{w}_{0})-F^{\star})+\frac{4K\kappa}{ND^{2}}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(1-a_{k}^{\star}[n+1])D_{k}^{2}\leq\epsilon^{\star}\leq\hat{\epsilon}, (60)

which implies that ℰ⋆superscriptℰ⋆\mathcal{E}^{\star} is also a feasible solution of problem (20) with ϵ^^italic-ϵ\hat{\epsilon}. Since ∑δ^​[n]^𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\sum{\hat{\delta}}[n] is the minimum objective value of problem (20) with ϵ^^italic-ϵ\hat{\epsilon}, it follows that ∑δ⋆​[n]≥∑δ^​[n]superscript𝛿⋆delimited-[]𝑛^𝛿delimited-[]𝑛\sum\delta^{\star}[n]\geq\sum\hat{\delta}[n], which thus completes the proof of Theorem 2.

-D Proof of Theorem 3

Let the first derivative of the objective function of problem (IV-A) w.r.t. τk​[n]subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛\tau_{k}[n] be zeros, i.e.,

∑k=1Kμk​[n]+λk​σ2hk​[n]​(2ak​[n]​sB​τk​[n]−ak​[n]​s​ln⁡2B​τk​[n]​2ak​[n]​sB​τk​[n]−1)=0.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜆𝑘superscript𝜎2subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript2subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠2𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscript2subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛10\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\!\mu_{k}[n]\!+\!\lambda_{k}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{h_{k}[n]}\Big{(}\!2^{\frac{a_{k}[n]s}{B\tau_{k}[n]}}\!-\!\frac{a_{k}[n]s\ln 2}{B\tau_{k}[n]}2^{\frac{a_{k}[n]s}{B\tau_{k}[n]}}\!-\!1\!\Big{)}\!=\!0. (61)

We can rewritten equation (61) as

(ak​[n]​s​ln⁡2B​τk​[n]−1)​2ak​[n]​sB​τk​[n]=hk​[n]​∑k=1Kμk​[n]λk​σ2−1.subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠2𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1superscript2subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝜆𝑘superscript𝜎21\displaystyle\Big{(}\frac{a_{k}[n]s\ln 2}{B\tau_{k}[n]}-1\Big{)}2^{\frac{a_{k}[n]s}{B\tau_{k}[n]}}=\frac{h_{k}[n]\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mu_{k}[n]}{\lambda_{k}\sigma^{2}}-1. (62)

By solving the above equation, one can have ak​[n]​s​ln⁡2B​τk​[n]−1=𝒲​(hk​[n]​∑k=1Kμk​[n]e​λk​σ2−1e).subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠2𝐵subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛1𝒲subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑒subscript𝜆𝑘superscript𝜎21𝑒\frac{a_{k}[n]s\ln 2}{B\tau_{k}[n]}-1=\mathcal{W}\Big{(}\frac{h_{k}[n]\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mu_{k}[n]}{e\lambda_{k}\sigma^{2}}-\frac{1}{e}\Big{)}. By simplifying the above equation, we can have that

τk​[n]=ak​[n]​s​ln⁡2B​(𝒲​(hk​[n]​∑k=1Kμk​[n]e​λk​σ2−1e)+1).subscript𝜏𝑘delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑎𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑠2𝐵𝒲subscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑘delimited-[]𝑛𝑒subscript𝜆𝑘superscript𝜎21𝑒1\displaystyle\tau_{k}[n]=\frac{a_{k}[n]s\ln 2}{B\Big{(}\mathcal{W}\Big{(}\frac{h_{k}[n]\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mu_{k}[n]}{e\lambda_{k}\sigma^{2}}-\frac{1}{e}\Big{)}+1\Big{)}}. (63)

Thus, this completes the proof.

-E Proof of Proposition 2

We denote T⋆​(𝑨⋆,𝚪⋆,𝜹⋆,𝑸⋆)=∑n=1Nδ⋆​[n]superscript𝑇⋆superscript𝑨⋆superscript𝚪⋆superscript𝜹⋆superscript𝑸⋆superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscript𝛿⋆delimited-[]𝑛T^{\star}(\bm{A}^{\star},\bm{\Gamma}^{\star},\bm{\delta}^{\star},\bm{Q}^{\star})=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\delta^{\star}[n] as the objective value of problem (20) with solution {𝑨⋆,𝚪⋆,𝜹⋆,𝑸⋆}superscript𝑨⋆superscript𝚪⋆superscript𝜹⋆superscript𝑸⋆\{\bm{A}^{\star},\bm{\Gamma}^{\star},\bm{\delta}^{\star},\bm{Q}^{\star}\}. As shown in step 5 of Algorithm 3, a feasible solution of problem (40) (i.e., {𝑨r,𝚪r,𝜹r,𝑸r}superscript𝑨𝑟superscript𝚪𝑟superscript𝜹𝑟superscript𝑸𝑟\{\bm{A}^{r},\bm{\Gamma}^{r},\bm{\delta}^{r},\bm{Q}^{r}\}) is also feasible to problem (25). We denote {𝑨r,𝚪r,𝜹r,𝑸r}superscript𝑨𝑟superscript𝚪𝑟superscript𝜹𝑟superscript𝑸𝑟\{\bm{A}^{r},\bm{\Gamma}^{r},\bm{\delta}^{r},\bm{Q}^{r}\} and {𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1,𝑸r+1}superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1superscript𝑸𝑟1\{\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1},\bm{Q}^{r+1}\} as a feasible solution of problem (20) at the r𝑟r-th and (r+1)𝑟1(r+1)-th iterations, respectively.

Because, given 𝑸rsuperscript𝑸𝑟\bm{Q}^{r} as shown in step 4 of Algorithm 3, {𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1}superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1\{\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1}\} is the optimal solution to problem (25), we have

T​(𝑨r,𝚪r,𝜹r,𝑸r)≥T​(𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1,𝑸r).𝑇superscript𝑨𝑟superscript𝚪𝑟superscript𝜹𝑟superscript𝑸𝑟𝑇superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1superscript𝑸𝑟\displaystyle T(\bm{A}^{r},\bm{\Gamma}^{r},\bm{\delta}^{r},\bm{Q}^{r})\geq T(\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1},\bm{Q}^{r}). (64)

Similarly, given 𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1} as shown in step 5 of Algorithm 3, 𝑸r+1superscript𝑸𝑟1\bm{Q}^{r+1} is the optimal solution to problem (41), it follows that

T​(𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1,𝑸r)=T​(𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1,𝑸r+1).𝑇superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1superscript𝑸𝑟𝑇superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1superscript𝑸𝑟1\displaystyle\!\!\!\!T(\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1},\bm{Q}^{r})\!=\!T(\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1},\bm{Q}^{r+1}). (65)

This holds because the original objective function T𝑇T is independent of 𝑸𝑸\bm{Q} but depends on 𝜹𝜹\bm{\delta}. Based on (​64​)italic-(64italic-)\eqref{p1} and (​65​)italic-(65italic-)\eqref{p3}, we further obtain

T​(𝑨r+1,𝚪r+1,𝜹r+1,𝑸r+1)≤T​(𝑨r,𝚪r,𝜹r,𝑸r),𝑇superscript𝑨𝑟1superscript𝚪𝑟1superscript𝜹𝑟1superscript𝑸𝑟1𝑇superscript𝑨𝑟superscript𝚪𝑟superscript𝜹𝑟superscript𝑸𝑟\displaystyle T(\bm{A}^{r+1},\bm{\Gamma}^{r+1},\bm{\delta}^{r+1},\bm{Q}^{r+1})\leq T(\bm{A}^{r},\bm{\Gamma}^{r},\bm{\delta}^{r},\bm{Q}^{r}), (66)

which shows that the objective value of problem (20) is always decreasing over iterations. Therefore, the proposed BCD-LD algorithm converges. This thus completes the proof.
